p.s: The scene in chapter 24 of the novel The Hate U Give portrays StarrsStarr's final moment of speaking herself free of her anger and her experianceexperience.
The scene starts with a describtiondescription by the first perosn of the situation; Starr, Seven, DeVante and Chris meet a demonstration which is leadedlead by Just Us For Justice.
The demonstration is nearby the place where Khalil died and at first Starr feels a bit unconfident and gets a flashback of his death.
This reminds the reader of what happened and shows how this experience still affects Starr.

This point of view also gives a very limited perspective, while Starr has her flashback the recipient has no idea what is going on, which creates the effect that the flashback holds Starr and that she is not even able to focus on anything else: I haven't been back here since that night.Knowing this is where Khalil... I stare too hard the crowd disappears, and I see him lying in the street [...] (ll. 5-7).
After that Starr comes back to reality because of the crowd.
A hairbrush is not a gun(l. 8), she describes her feelings: The voice snaps me from my daze. That shows that she dodoes not know how to deal with the flashbacks.
She concentrates back on her real situation, seesees Ms. Ofrah and realizes that her life is way more radical than she has expected.
Seven, DeVante and Chris starts to join the crowd, first Starr repeats quiet thanthen she remembers the situation with Khalil again; she rememberremembers what he said.
This gives the reader the feeling of realization; Starr has been through a lot and the reader can identify a lot with StarrsStarr's anger.
The anger comes thanthen to a final: she screams as loud as she can and through the development of her first speaking quiet, thanthen speaking so loud the tightening lows a bit.

This development from a watcher to a speaker as part of the crowd and later to a speaker in front of the crowd is highlighted by the flashbacks, it comes to a realization that she cannot stay quiet if she wants justice for Khalil and peace for herself.
While speaking to Ms. Ofrah she isvery sure taht she ahs to do something.
Ms. Ofrah tells her that she ahs to use her voice as a weapon.
At this point Starr realizes that she dodoes not have to burn something down to change something; she starts to understand that her voice is even more effective.
Here is also an appeal for the reader; everyone is in the position to speak for them selvesthemselves to change something.
Before Starr even starts to talk infrontin front of the crowd she has a moment of unsurnessinsecurity; this shows the reader that to be brave to speak up is not easy.
But by the moment when the crowd encourageencourages her the novel shows that there is always a savesafe place to speak up even if this place is not easy to find.
The line 57-58: Forget trigger happy - speaker happy is more my thing She notices that speaking herself free makes her happy.

The fact that no other person DeVante, Seven, Chris or Ms. Ofrah is mentioned at the moment when she speaks up shows that Starr is the only witness and because of that it is her own fight for her own better ending.
For her self-development in the novel this is very important: it does not matter that she has two worlds to live in or that she is not sure who she is.
The only thing that mattermatters here is the fact taht she is brave enough to tell her truth by her own voice.
